t: Psalm 78
Tell the Coming Generation
A Maskil of Asaph.
Give*pn ear, O my people, to my teaching; incline*ld your ears to the words of my mouth!
I*ln will open my mouth in a parable; I*ld will utter dark sayings from of old,
things*ln that we have heard and known, that*ld our fathers have told us.
We*ln will not hide them from their children, but*ld tell to the coming generation the*ln glorious deeds of the Lord,*s and his might, and*ld the wonders that he has done.
He*pn established a testimony in Jacob and*ld appointed a law in Israel, which*ln he commanded our fathers to*ld teach to their children,
that*ln the next generation might know them, the*ld children yet unborn, and*ln arise and tell them to their children,
so*ld that they should set their hope in God and*ln not forget the works of God, but*ld keep his commandments;
and*ln that they should not be like their fathers, a*ld stubborn and rebellious generation, a*ln generation whose heart was not steadfast, whose*ld spirit was not faithful to God.
The*pn Ephraimites, armed with the bow, turned*ld back on the day of battle.
They*ln did not keep God’s covenant, but*ld refused to walk according to his law.
They*ln forgot his works and*ld the wonders that he had shown them.
In*ln the sight of their fathers he performed wonders in*ld the land of Egypt, in the fields of Zoan.
He*ln divided the sea and let them pass through it, and*ld made the waters stand like a heap.
In*ln the daytime he led them with a cloud, and*ld all the night with a fiery light.
He*ln split rocks in the wilderness and*ld gave them drink abundantly as from the deep.
He*ln made streams come out of the rock and*ld caused waters to flow down like rivers.
Yet*pn they sinned still more against him, rebelling*ld against the Most High in the desert.
They*ln tested God in their heart by*ld demanding the food they craved.
They*ln spoke against God, saying, “Can*ld God spread a table in the wilderness?
He*ln struck the rock so that water gushed out and*ld streams overflowed. Can*ln he also give bread or*ld provide meat for his people?”
Therefore,*pn when the Lord*s heard, he was full of wrath; a*ld fire was kindled against Jacob; his*ld anger rose against Israel,
because*ln they did not believe in God and*ld did not trust his saving power.
Yet*ln he commanded the skies above and*ld opened the doors of heaven,
and*ln he rained down on them manna to eat and*ld gave them the grain of heaven.
Man*ln ate of the bread of the angels; he*ld sent them food in abundance.
He*ln caused the east wind to blow in the heavens, and*ld by his power he led out the south wind;
he*ln rained meat on them like dust, winged*ld birds like the sand of the seas;
he*ln let them fall in the midst of their camp, all*ld around their dwellings.
And*ln they ate and were well filled, for*ld he gave them what they craved.
But*ln before they had satisfied their craving, while*ld the food was still in their mouths,
the*ln anger of God rose against them, and*ld he killed the strongest of them and*ld laid low the young men of Israel.
In*pn spite of all this, they still sinned; despite*ld his wonders, they did not believe.
So*ln he made their days vanish like a breath, and*ld their years in terror.
When*ln he killed them, they sought him; they*ld repented and sought God earnestly.
They*ln remembered that God was their rock, the*ld Most High God their redeemer.
But*ln they flattered him with their mouths; they*ld lied to him with their tongues.
Their*ln heart was not steadfast toward him; they*ld were not faithful to his covenant.
Yet*ln he, being compassionate, atoned*ld for their iniquity and*ld did not destroy them; he*ln restrained his anger often and*ld did not stir up all his wrath.
He*ln remembered that they were but flesh, a*ld wind that passes and comes not again.
How*ln often they rebelled against him in the wilderness and*ld grieved him in the desert!
They*ln tested God again and again and*ld provoked the Holy One of Israel.
They*ln did not remember his power or*ld the day when he redeemed them from the foe,
when*ln he performed his signs in Egypt and*ld his marvels in the fields of Zoan.
He*ln turned their rivers to blood, so*ld that they could not drink of their streams.
He*ln sent among them swarms of flies, which devoured them, and*ld frogs, which destroyed them.
He*ln gave their crops to the destroying locust and*ld the fruit of their labor to the locust.
He*ln destroyed their vines with hail and*ld their sycamores with frost.
He*ln gave over their cattle to the hail and*ld their flocks to thunderbolts.
He*ln let loose on them his burning anger, wrath,*ld indignation, and distress, a*ld company of destroying angels.
He*ln made a path for his anger; he*ld did not spare them from death, but*ld gave their lives over to the plague.
He*ln struck down every firstborn in Egypt, the*ld firstfruits of their strength in the tents of Ham.
Then*ln he led out his people like sheep and*ld guided them in the wilderness like a flock.
He*ln led them in safety, so that they were not afraid, but*ld the sea overwhelmed their enemies.
And*ln he brought them to his holy land, to*ld the mountain which his right hand had won.
He*ln drove out nations before them; he*ld apportioned them for a possession and*ld settled the tribes of Israel in their tents.
Yet*pn they tested and rebelled against the Most High God and*ld did not keep his testimonies,
but*ln turned away and acted treacherously like their fathers; they*ld twisted like a deceitful bow.
For*ln they provoked him to anger with their high places; they*ld moved him to jealousy with their idols.
When*ln God heard, he was full of wrath, and*ld he utterly rejected Israel.
He*ln forsook his dwelling at Shiloh, the*ld tent where he dwelt among mankind,
and*ln delivered his power to captivity, his*ld glory to the hand of the foe.
He*ln gave his people over to the sword and*ld vented his wrath on his heritage.
Fire*ln devoured their young men, and*ld their young women had no marriage song.
Their*ln priests fell by the sword, and*ld their widows made no lamentation.
Then*ln the Lord awoke as from sleep, like*ld a strong man shouting because of wine.
And*ln he put his adversaries to rout; he*ld put them to everlasting shame.
He*pn rejected the tent of Joseph; he*ld did not choose the tribe of Ephraim,
but*ln he chose the tribe of Judah, Mount*ld Zion, which he loves.
He*ln built his sanctuary like the high heavens, like*ld the earth, which he has founded forever.
He*ln chose David his servant and*ld took him from the sheepfolds;
from*ln following the nursing ewes he brought him to*ld shepherd Jacob his people, Israel*ld his inheritance.
With*ln upright heart he shepherded them and*ld guided them with his skillful hand.
